items: Overview of tick-borne illnesses commonly seen in the U.S.
Comparison of clinical features of 3 infections transmitted by Ixodes species ticks (in the U.S.) (images below)
Concomitant infections with two, or even three, of the 3 pathogens can occur: e.g. Lyme + Babesia or Lyme + Anaplasmosis (HGA)

Ixodes sp. ticks are also the vector for a cause of relapsing fever (Borrelia miyamoto) and a tick borne encephalitis (Powassan disease). Relapsing fever is also caused by other species of ticks, e.g., soft ticks.
In Europe and Asia, Ixodes ticks are the vector for other diseases, including tick-borne encephalitis (TBE).
See Tick-Borne Encephalitis, Vaccines for indications, available products, dosing, and vaccine characteristics for pre-exposure prevention.

items: Lyme: see Lyme Disease, Diagnosis.

Multiplex antibody test for 8 tick borne infections: Anaplasma, Babesia, Borrelia burgdorferi, Borellia miyamotoi, Ehrlichia, Ricketsia rickettsi, Heartland virus, and Powassan virus (Sci Rep 8:3158, 2018).
Ref: Multiplex PCR tests for tick-borne illnesses in children: Open Forum Infect Dis. 2023, 10:ofad121.
See CDC geographic distribution of tick-borne disease.
Tickborne diseases/pathogens acquired in the United states as per the CDC in alphabetical order:
Anaplasmosis [Anaplasma (Ehrlichia) phagocytophilum]
Babesiosis (Protozoan)
Relapsing fever (Borrelia miyamotoi and Borrelia mayonii): spirochetes (Am J Med. 2019; 132:136))
Bourbon virus ?
Colorado tick fever virus
Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever Virus
Ehrlichiosis (E. chaffeensis, E. wingii, E. muris-like)
Fever with thrombocytopenia virus
Heartland virus: Similar geography as Ehrlichia chaffeensis (Human monocytic ehrlichiosis)
Lyme Disease Overview
Powassan disease virus (New Engl J Med. 2019; 380: 380)
Rickettsia parkeri: Rickettsia (see Rickettsia, Not spotted fever Group)
Rocky Mountain spotted fever: Rickettsia
Southern tick-associated rash illness
Tick-borne relapsing fever: Spirochetes
Tularemia: Francisella tularensis bacteria
364D rickettsiosis (Eschar-associated illness in California: Clin Infect Dis 50:541, 2010)
Tick-borne illnesses acquired in other parts of the world (non-U.S.):
Neoehrlichia mikurensis (emerging - mostly EU, possibly Asia)
Tick transmitted organisms visible in peripheral blood smear:
In cytoplasm of Neutrophils: Anaplasmosis (HGA)
In cytoplasm of Monocytes: Ehhlichiosis
In erythrocytes: Babesia
In plasma: Borrelia: Relapsing fever
